Description.val: The Conventional Munitions Demilitarization Program provides for the demilitarization (demil) and disposal of Single Manger for Conventional Ammunition (SMCA) conventional ammunition for all Military Services per DoD Directive 5160.65 and DoD Instruction 5160.68 that is unserviceable, obsolete, unsafe, or excess to requirements.  The program accomplishes demil using open burning/open detonation (OB/OD) processes or closed disposal technologies (CDT) with primary emphasis on resource recovery and recycling (R3).  This program also provides for operations and technical support and services; packaging, crating, handling, and transportation (PCHT) of ammunition for demil projects at US Army depots, plants and activities; commercial contracts that provide CDT demil support and services, and international operations, which include the European and Pacific Theatres.

Justification.val:
FY 2014 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $179.605 million will support the demilitarization of conventional ammunition as well as missile and missile components.

FY 2014 funds will support the United States (US) demil operations of conventional ammunition at the Demilitarization Facility (DEFAC) in the Republic of Korea (ROK).  A Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) was signed on 4 November 2011 by US Forces Korea and the ROK permitting demil of US titled munitions.

As of the end of September 2012, the conventional ammunition demil account contained 608,822 tons of ammunition in Continental United States (CONUS) wholesale storage locations: 555,789 tons of conventional ammunition and 53,033 tons of missiles and/or missile components (msl/comp).  As of the end of September 2012, 81,509 tons of conventional ammunition have been demilitarized with 73,677 tons planned for FY 2013.  As of the end of September 2012, 263,256 msl/comp have been demilitarized exceeding the 210,996 msl/comp planned for FY 2012 due to an unforeseen increase is the number of components (small parts).  

Stockpile growth and generations.  An estimated 111,282 tons of conventional ammunition will be generated into the SMCA Resource, Recovery and Disposition Account (B5A) in FY 2013 and 116,373 tons in FY 2014.  For FY 2015 through FY 2019 513,448 tons of conventional ammunition are forecasted to be added into the B5A.  For missile demil, an estimated 99,486 msl/comp are planned for generations into the B5A in FY 2013 and 105,779 msl/comp in FY 2014.  For FY 2015 through FY 2019, 216,880 msl/comp are forecasted to be added into the B5A.

Stockpile growth factors.  The demil stockpile is expected to grow as a result of Military Services generations and will also be driven by other factors such as cluster munitions, land mine policies and the disestablishment of War Reserve Stocks Allies (WRSA) accounts at Outside Continental United States (OCONUS) locations.  There are currently approximately 186,000 tons of cluster munitions in the demil stockpile.  To ensure compliance with the Cluster Munitions Policy, an additional 339,000 tons are expected to be added into the B5A no later than FY 2018.
